titleStmt.title: The Girl who Wanted to Fly
titleStmt.author: Anonymous

respStmt.resp: Encoded in TEI P5 XML by
respStmt.name: Michael Widner
Clara Romani

availability.p: The Global Medieval Sourcebook is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

notesStmt.p: Fabliaux are a genre of short tales in verse from late medieval France, which were written and performed by jongleurs, a type of minstrel. Joseph Bédier provides the classic definition of the genre as “contes à rire en vers” [stories in verse to laugh at]. The typical metrical form of the fabliau is octosyllabic rhymed couplets, the most common verse form in medieval French literature. Fabliaux are often obscene, full of scatological and sexual humor; many feature rape and other forms of sexual violence that can be quite graphic and disturbing. They also often express strong anticlerical and anti-nobility sentiments. “La pucele qui voloit voler” (“The girl who wanted to fly”) is highly representative of the genre in its themes, plot, style, and characters. In this poem, a beautiful and courtly maiden (la pucele) is pursued by a group of suitors, all of whom she rejects. One day, she announces that she would like to be able to fly. Several young men construct wings for her, which do not work. One day, a cleric (li clers) convinces her that she needs a beak and a tail to fly, as all birds possess these things. He offers to make them for her, to which she readily assents. The two close themselves in a room and the clerk begins to kiss her “more than thirty times,” explaining that he is fashioning the beak. Then, he begins work on the tail, at which the lady expresses pleasure. Both the beak and the tail exemplify the use of euphemism and misnaming common in fabliaux. Norris J. Lacy writes that, in fabliaux, the “refusal to call things by their ordinary names will lead directly to the precise result, usually sexual intercourse, that the euphemisms were designed to preclude” (44). “La pucele” is no exception. When the lady in this tale learns that the clerk won’t be able to complete her tail in less than a year, she keeps him with her so she can achieve her goal of flying. Naturally, the lady becomes pregnant; she then complains that the clerk tricked her. He explains to her, however, that her pregnancy is entirely natural. It was her wish to fly that was unnatural. The lesson of the tale, then, is that people who have excessive or outrageous desires will pay the consequences.

“La pucele” exists in three different manuscripts, each of which is a compilation of fabliaux and similar short verse tales. Each version of the tale is largely the same, but with some differences in details. The manuscripts are Bern, Burgerbibliothek 354, folio 43ra-44ra (Witness B); Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, fr. 1593, folio 187rb-188ra (Witness E); and Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, fr. 25545, folio 4vb-5vb (Witness I). This edition follows the witness naming conventions found in the Nouveau Recueil Complet des Fabliaux (NRCF). The longest of the three manuscripts is I, which has a 26 verse epilogue, compared to 7 verses in B and 9 in E. Each text shows evidence of divergences from what scholars assume to have been the (now lost) original text. The critical text, which we have drawn from the NRCF, tracks most closely with B, despite some omissions in B. Of the three manuscripts, B is the most legible and most well-preserved, despite some holes in the parchment. E is nearly as legible as B. I is the least legible, showing signs of multiple repairs to the manuscript, irregularly lined columns, and multiple illegible sections due to faded or scraped ink. B has red and blue initials and rubrics in a pale red. E has spaces reserved for miniatures and other decorations that were never completed. I uses red ink for majuscules and rubrics. In all three manuscripts, the fabliau’s author is unnamed. The text is also difficult to date or locate with any precision. Each manuscript is believed to be from the late 13th or early 14thcentury. I has been dated most precisely as between the end of 1316 and April 3, 1317. As a result, the original date for the composition of “La pucele” is suspected to be sometime in the mid- to late 13th century.
Bédier, Joseph. Les fabliaux: études de littérature populaire et d’histoire littéraire du Moyen Âge. E. Champion, 1925.
Crocker, Holly A. Comic Provocations: Exposing the Corpus of Old French Fabliaux. Springer, 2006.
Crocker, Holly A. “Disfiguring Gender: Masculine Desire in the Old French Fabliau.” Exemplaria, vol. 23, no. 4, 2011, pp. 342-367.
DuVal, John, and Raymond Eichmann. Cuckolds, Clerics, & Countrymen: Medieval French Fabliaux. U of Arkansas P, 1982.
Noomen, Willem and Nico van den Boogaard. Nouveau Recueil Complet des Fabliaux, vol. 6, 1991, pp. 151-170.
Lacy, Norris J. Reading Fabliaux. Routledge, 2013.
“The Girl Who Wanted to Fly,” The Fabliaux: A New Verse Translation. Translated by Nathaniel E. Dubin. Liveright Publishing Corporation, 2013, pp. 339–344.
Parsons, Ben. “The English Fabliau in the 15th and 16th Centuries.” Literature Compass, vol. 10, no. 7, 2013, pp. 544-558.
Parsons, Ben. “No Laughing Matter: Fraud, the Fabliau and Chaucer’s Franklin’s Tale.” Neophilologus vol. 96, no. 1, 2012, pp. 121-136.
Pearcy, Roy. Logic and Humour in the Fabliaux: An Essay in Applied Narratology. DS Brewer, 2007.
Perfetti, Lisa. “The Lewd and the Ludic: Female Pleasure in the Fabliaux.” Comic Provocations: Exposing the Corpus of Old French Fabliaux. Palgrave Macmillan, 2006, pp. 17-31.
Schenck, Mary Jane Stearns. The Fabliaux: Tales of Wit and Deception. John Benjamins Publishing, 1987.

listWit.witness: The Girl who Wanted to Fly
De la damoisele qui uost voler
De la pucelle qui vouloit voler
Ci aprés commence d'une damoisele qui onques por nelui ne'se volt marier. Mais volt voler en l'aire

projectDesc.p: "The Girl who Wanted to Fly" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

When lines from one manuscript witness appear to be related closely to lines in another, regardless of order, they have been connected in the critical apparatus. For example, see B l.80, E l.75, an I l.91, in which the language between E and I match each other, but the sense matches that of B, which is the primary source of the critical text.

The critical text and manuscript transcriptions are drawn from the NRCF (pp. 155–170). The translation is a new, diplomatic translation by Michael Widner that attempts to follow the critical text as faithfully as possible. All variants are linked to show where they share lines and where they diverge. Digital facsimiles of the manuscripts in which each variant appears are also included in the appropriate locations.

segmentation.p: Each witness has been encoded line-by-line, with line numbers remaining consistent within each witness. Links have been established across witnesses through paralell segmentation.

app.lem: La pucele qui vouloit voler
app.rdg: De la damoisele qui uost voler
De la pucelle qui vouloit voler
Ci aprés commence d'une damoisele qui onques por nelui ne'se volt marier. Mais volt voler en l'aire
The Girl who Wanted to Fly

app.lem: D'une damoisele vos voil
app.rdg: I want to tell you about

app.lem: Conter c'onques ne virent oil
app.rdg: Que onques ne virent mi oil
A lady; eyes have never seen

app.lem: Si bele com ele estoit,
app.rdg: Si bele riens com ele estoit
Plus bele riens com ele estoit

app.lem: Et de biauté grant los avoit.
app.rdg: Et de biauté grant los auoit
De grant biauté le los auoit
Et de bonté. grant los auoit
And she drew great praise for her beauty.

app.lem: De riches clers, de chevaliers,
app.rdg: By clerks of great means, by knights,

app.lem: Et de borjois et d'escuiers
Estoit totes eures requise,
app.rdg: She was beseeched all the time,

app.lem: Mes ne voloit en nule guise
app.rdg: Mes ne voloit en nule guise
Mais ne vouloit en nule guise
But she did not in any way

app.lem: La priere a nul escouter.
Un jor dit qu'el voudroit voler.
app.rdg: One day she said that she would like to fly.
Volentiers par mi l'air la sus
Si bien com vns oisiaus ou plus

app.lem: Sachiez que plusors genz l'oïrent:
app.rdg: You should know that several people heard her:

app.lem: A mervelles s'en esbaïrent.
app.rdg: They were marvelously shocked by it.

app.lem: Eles li firent damoisel
De cire et de pennes d'oisel;
app.rdg: De cire et de pennes d'oisiaus

app.lem: As braz et as costez li mistrent,
app.rdg: Es bras. et ens costés li mist
They put it on her flanks and arms,

app.lem: Et, ce sachiez, mout s'entremistrent
app.rdg: And, mark this, they put great care

app.lem: De li cointement acesmer:
Mais ainz por ce ne pot voler.
app.rdg: Mens ainz por'ce ne pot uoler
Mais ains por'ce ne pot voler
But for all that she could not fly.

app.lem: Uns clers li dist: "Ce ne valt rien,
app.rdg: Vns clers li dist ce ne vaut rien
A clerk said to her: "This won't work,

app.lem: Damoisele, ce sachiez bien!
Il vos convendra atorner
Autrement se volez voler:
app.rdg: Differently if you want to fly:

app.lem: Que bec vos convendra avoir
app.rdg: Because you need to have a beak

app.lem: Et queue, ce sachiez de voir,
app.rdg: Et queue ce sachiez de uoir

app.lem: Que nus oisaus sanz ce ne vole.
app.rdg: Et nus oisaus sanz ce ne uole
Because no bird flies without these.

app.lem: - Je gree bien ceste parole,
Fait la pucele, et je l'otroi.
app.rdg: Said the girl, and I agree to it.

app.lem: Qui fera ce? Dites lou moi!
app.rdg: Who will do it? Tell me!

app.lem: — Damoisele, fet il, je sui!
Se vos commandez, encor hui
Vos cuit je fere plus bel bec
app.rdg: Vos cuit ie fere plus bel bec
I will make you the most beautiful beak

app.lem: Et miaus fet que n'a nul espec;
app.rdg: Et miaus fet qu'il n'a nul espec

app.lem: Plus bele qeue vos ferai
app.rdg: I will make you a tail more beautiful

app.lem: Que poons, que ja n'i faudrai!"
app.rdg: Than a peacock's, I won't disappoint!"

app.lem: A tant en une chanbre entrerent
app.rdg: A tant en une chanbre entrerent
So they went into a room

app.lem: En l'uis sor aus mout bien fermerent.
app.rdg: Et l'uis sor aus | mout bien fermerent
And shut the door firmly behind them.

app.lem: Li clers en un lit la cocha:
app.rdg: The clerk threw her on a bed:

app.lem: Plus de trente fois la besa.
app.rdg: And he kissed her more than thirty times.

app.lem: Ele demande que c'estoit;
Il dit que lou bec li faisoit.
app.rdg: Jl dit que lou'bec li faisoit
He said that he was making her a beak.

app.lem: "Fet lo l'en donc en tel maniere?
app.rdg: Fet lo l'en donc en'tel maniere
"So is that how one does it?

app.lem: — Oïl, tornez vos par derriere,
Que la coe i enterai.
app.rdg: So I can graft the tail.

app.lem: — Danz clers, fet ele, je ferai
app.rdg: — Mister clerk, she said, I will do

app.lem: Tot ce que vos m'ensaigneroiz,
Mes gardez que vos n'i failloiz!"
app.rdg: But be careful you do not fail me!"

app.lem: Cele se torne a estupons.
app.rdg: She then got on her hands and knees.

app.lem: Il li enbat jusqu'as coillons

app.rdg: He beat his cock in her cunt

app.lem: Lo vit el con, sanz contredit.

app.rdg: Up to his balls, without objection.

app.lem: Et la damoisele li dit
app.rdg: And the lady spoke to him

app.lem: Et demande comment ce vet:
app.rdg: And asked how this was happening:

app.lem: Il dit que sa coe li fet.
app.rdg: He said he was making her tail.

app.lem: "Danz clers, fait el, or esploitiez!
app.rdg: Danz clers fait el or esploitiez
"Mister clerk, she said, hurry up now!

app.lem: Botez parfont, si l'atachiez
app.rdg: Push it in deep, and attach it

app.lem: Si fermement qu'ele ne chiee.
app.rdg: So strongly that it won't fall out.

app.lem: Je seré si aparrelliee,
Quant je vos departirai,
Bien cuit que je voler porrai."
app.rdg: Bien cuit que ie uoler porrai
Methinks I will be able to fly."

app.lem: Et li clers bote adés en l'angle,
app.rdg: Et li clers bote adés en l'angle
And the clerk immediately thrust in the angle,

app.lem: Cui il n'est gaires de sa jangle.
app.rdg: Cui il n'est gaires de sa iangle
And he didn't care much about what she was saying.

app.lem: Quant ot de li fet son talant,
app.rdg: Quant ot de'li fet son talant
When he had from her what he wanted,

app.lem: El lit s'asist demaintenant
app.rdg: He sat down on the bed

app.lem: Et la damoisele lez lui.
app.rdg: With the lady next to him.

app.lem: "Danz clers, fet ele, don n'iert hui
app.rdg: Danz clers fet ele don n'iert huj
"Mister clerk, she said, won't the tail

app.lem: Ceste qeue tote parfete?
Fetes la tost, que mout me hete!"
app.rdg: Fetes la tost que mout me'hete
complete it quickly, because I can't wait!"

app.lem: La boche li bese et la face,
app.rdg: She kissed his mouth and face,

app.lem: Et si li prie que il face
app.rdg: Et si'li prie que il face
And so beseeched him to make

app.lem: La qeue tost, se Dieus l'i salt.
"Do bec, fet ele, ne me chalt:
app.rdg: "The beak," she said, "I don't care about it:

app.lem: Ce puet assez metre en respit!"
De la queue li prie et dit
app.rdg: About the tail she begged him and said

app.lem: Que il la face sanz demore.
app.rdg: That he should make it without delay.

app.lem: Li clers dist: "Se Dieus me secore,
app.rdg: The clerk said: "May God save me,

app.lem: El n'iert fete devant un an.
app.rdg: It won't be done before a year.

app.lem: — Dan clers, fet el, par saint Jehan,
app.rdg: Dan clers fet el par saint iehan
— Mister clerk, she said, by Saint John,

app.lem: Ja de moi ne departiroiz,
Devant que vos fete l'avroiz!"
Il remest o la damoisele,
Car la parole li fu bele,
app.rdg: Car la parole li fu bele

app.lem: Et de la queue s'entremist:
app.rdg: And he busied himself with the tail:

app.lem: Chascun jor un petit en fist.
app.rdg: Each day he made a little bit of it.

app.lem: Tant l'empainst et tant i hurta
app.rdg: He thrust and banged there so much

app.lem: Que la damoisele engroissa.

note.p: After this line, each manuscript diverges considerably. B and E stay near one another, but the order of verses is modified. I leaves out several passages that exist in B and E while adding several others that describe the situation of the pregnant girl. Because the transition in B and E from this line to the next seems rather abrupt, it's possible that the additions in I contain an echo of some verses that existed in the original manuscript, but which were lost in B and E.

app.lem: "Hé, dit, clers, vos m'avez gabee!
app.rdg: Et dit clers uos m'auez gabee

app.lem: La queue m'est el cors germee:
app.rdg: The tail germinated in my body:

app.lem: Je cuit que je soie engroissiee.
Malement m'avez engingniee:
Je ne puis seulement aler!
Comment porroie je voler?
app.rdg: How will I be able to fly?

app.lem: Empiriee sui durement:
Bien savez engignier la gent!"
app.rdg: You really know how to trick people!"

app.lem: Li clers li dist: "Par saint Amant,
app.rdg: Li'clers li dist par saint amant
The clerk said to her: "By Saint Amand,

app.lem: Vos m'alez a grant tort blasmant,
Que, par la foi que je vos doi,
app.rdg: Que par la foi que'ie uos doi
Because, by the faith I owe you,

app.lem: N'iestes pas descreüe en moi!
Se grosse iestes, ce est nature,
app.rdg: Se grosse iestes ce est nature
If you are pregnant, that was nature's feat,

app.lem: Mes ce estoit grant desmesure
Que par l'aire voliez voler:
app.rdg: To want to fly through the air:

app.lem: Trop par en faites a blasmer,
De poi estes apesantie."
En tel maniere l'a servie
app.rdg: In this way he served her

app.lem: Com vos poez ici oïr.
Et ce l'en doit bien avenir:
app.rdg: And this is the outcome she deserves:

app.lem: Qui otrage quiert il li vient!
app.rdg: Who seeks too much will get it!

app.lem: Por ce de ceste me sovient
app.rdg: For this reason I remember this girl

app.lem: Qui trop estoit desmesuree:
Issi li fu la qeue entee.
app.rdg: Jssi li fu la qeue entee
And thus had a tail grafted to her.
Sachiez que mout des genz l'oirent.
.J. clers li dit ce ne vaut rien
Et queue ie uos di por uoir
Que nus oyseaus sanz ce ne vole
Dit la'pucele et si le croi.
Quant sera ce dites le moi
Dame dit li clers tot prest sui
Se uos le comandez encor hui
Vos quit ie fere plus biau bec
Et mieus assis que nul espec
Que nus paons ia n'i faudrai.
A tant en une chambre entrerent
Et l'uis seur eus mout bien fremerent
Li clers en .i. lit la coucha
Et il dit que bec li fesoit
Fet on donc bec en tel maniere
Danz clers dit ele ie ferai
Mes gardez que vod ne foulliez
Le vit ou con sanz contredit
Jl dit que la queue li met
Dans clers dit ele or esploitiez
Et li clers boute iusqu'en l'angle
Ne li chaut gueres de sa iangle
Quant de li ot fet son talent
Dans clers dit ele ce n'iert hui
Fetes la tost. car mout me hete
En la bouche et en la face
La baise et li dit que face
La queue tost se deus me saut
Du bec des eles ne me chaut
Je les metrai bien en respit
De la queue li prie et dit
Que il la face sanz demure
Li clers dit se deus me sequeure
Dans clers dit ele par saint iehan
Au clerc plut mont ceste nouele

app.lem: Petit et petit nuit et ior

app.rdg: Lors dit clers vos m'auez gabee
La queue m'est ou cors germee
Je sai bien que ie sui encainte.

app.lem: Empiriee sui malement
Pris ai mauués amendement

app.rdg: A paine puis ie me aler
Li'clers li dit par saint amant
Vos m'alez a grant tort blamant
Que par la foy que ie vos doi
Se grosse estes ce est nature
Et ce l'en dut bien auenir
Qui outrage quiert il li vient
Por ce de ceste me souient
Et si li fu la queue entee

app.lem: Com vos ici auez oi
Du clerc qui mie ne failli
Puis espousa la damoisele
A cui l'auenture fu bele.
Explicit.

app.rdg: Nus oisiaus sans coe ne vole
Je croi mout bien ceste parole
Fait la pucele. et or l'otroy
Dame ce dist li clers je sui
Bel et bien a vostre deuise
Car l'art dou faire bien en sai

Bec. eles. et coe vos faut
Witness I has numerous extra lines that are not attested to in other manuscripts. Here, eight lines are added that describe how the cleric will fashion a beak (bec), wings (eles), and a tail (coe). The editors of the NRCF note that the structure of the story is weakened by the addition of this detail because, apparently, the scribe forgot that the girl had already been given wings by another young man (p. 337).
Por vous faire voler en haut
Por vos en l'air faire voler
Tout dui en la chambre entrerent
Et l'uis sur aus mout bien fermerent
Li clers en .j. lit la coucha
Et par maintes fois la baisa
Cis dist que le bec li faisoit
Mout se painne de plaire a'li
Jl dist. les eles li cousoit
Faites les vos en tel meniere
Car ie vos veul la coe faire
Le vit ens cors. sans contredit
Cis li dist. que la coe fait

app.lem: Et la besoingne par compas
Ne veul pas que ce soit a'gas
Que la chose ne soit bien faite
Et sil de bien ferir se haite

app.rdg: Or tost car mout bien esploitiez
Si tres forment qu'ele ne chiee
Que bien croi que ie volerai

app.lem: Li clers etent a'son affaire
Et pence de sa coe faire
Ne li chaut gaires c'ele hoingne
Mout bien entant a sa besoingne

app.rdg: Quant il ot fait tout son talent
Dans clers dist ele donc n'iert hui
Fait la tost car mout me haite
Ne me chaut il certes nient
De la coe sur toute rien
Vos pri. que vous l'atachiez bien
Clers par la foy que iedoi

app.lem: De l'autre afaire t si poi

app.rdg: Au clerc plait mout ceste nouele
Chascun iour. vn petit en fist
Tant il pont en tant il hurta

app.lem: La coe li a si antee
Qu'ele est en cors enracinee
Si bien que ia n'en istera
Jusqu'a'tens. qu'el. enfentera
Cele a'la'terre se roilloit
Qui deuant haut voler vouloit
Et se clamme lasse cheitiue
Mieus vorroit morir qu'estre uiue

app.rdg: Ha dans clers vos m'auez gabee

app.lem: Appessantie suis forment
Ne me puis ceindre ne leuer

app.rdg: Vos m'alez a grant tort blasmant
Car par la foy que ie vous doy
Qui outrage quiert il li vient
A cui la coe fu entee

app.lem: C'onques ne se vout marier
A nelui. tant la seut prier
Or soupire or plore des ieus
Bien est abatus ses orguieus
Par .j. vallant clerc et estrange
Qui ainsis l'a laissiee au lange
Mout en y'a ancor de celes
Et des dames et des puceles
Qui tost ainsis le sont. ou pis
qui aurient bien de bons maris
mais ne gaingnent qu'orguieus les vaint
Ainsis en uoi maintes. et maint
Les vnes sont si pou estables
Fergier se font en ses estables
A garcons ou a cherretiers
Qui puis en ont mauais luiers
Les autres prennent .j. vilain
Por ce vous consoil ie de plain
Vous qui auez oi cest conte
Orguieus desdaing ne vous sormonte
Mariez vos seloncs le tens
Adonc quant lieus en iert et tens
